abstract.title: Objective:
abstract.p: Evaluate the association of evidence-based opioid prescribing guidelines with new persistent opioid use after surgery.

sec.title: Summary Background Data:
sec.p: Patients exposed to opioids after surgery are at risk of new persistent opioid use, which is associated with opioid use disorder and overdose. It is unknown whether evidence-based opioid prescribing guidelines mitigate this risk.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Using Medicare claims, we performed a difference-in-differences study of opioid-naive patients who underwent 1 of 6 common surgical procedures for which evidence-based postoperative opioid prescribing guidelines were released and disseminated through a statewide quality collaborative in Michigan in October 2017. The primary outcome was the incidence of new persistent opioid use, and the secondary outcome was total postoperative opioid prescription quantity in oral morphine equivalents (OME).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: We identified 24,908 patients who underwent surgery in Michigan and 118,665 patients who underwent surgery outside of Michigan. Following the release of prescribing guidelines in Michigan, the adjusted incidence of new persistent opioid use decreased from 3.29% (95% CI 3.15-3.43%) to 2.51% (95% CI 2.35-2.67%) in Michigan, which was an additional 0.53 (95% CI 0.36-0.69) percentage point decrease compared with patients outside of Michigan. Simultaneously, adjusted opioid prescription quantity decreased from 199.5 (95% CI 198.3-200.6) mg OME to 88.6 (95% CI 78.7-98.5) mg OME in Michigan, which was an additional 55.7 (95% CI 46.5-65.4) mg OME decrease compared with patients outside of Michigan.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Evidence-based opioid prescribing guidelines were associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of new persistent opioid use and the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery.

body.p: New persistent postoperative opioid use occurs when an opioid-naive patient receives a postoperative opioid prescription meant for short-term use but continues to fill additional opioid prescriptions for months after this initial exposure.1–4 New persistent opioid use after surgery is associated with an increased long-term risk of complications, opioid use disorder, overdose, and death.5–9 Chronic opioid use after surgery also burdens the healthcare system, as these prescriptions are ultimately managed by primary care physicians and patients have increased healthcare utilization and spending.10,11 Recognition of these risks has led to the development of evidence-based postoperative opioid prescribing guidelines.12–15 These guidelines have been shown to reduce the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery without compromising patient satisfaction or pain control.16

Despite the growing adoption of postoperative opioid prescribing guidelines, to date, no study has assessed whether these guidelines reduce the risk of developing chronic opioid use after surgery.17 Given that over 50 million operations are performed annually in the United States and most involve a postoperative opioid prescription, even a small reduction in the incidence of new persistent opioid use could have major implications for prescribing practice and patient safety.18

Therefore, we evaluated the change in new persistent opioid use after surgery following the statewide implementation of evidence-based opioid prescribing guidelines. In 2017, the Opioid Prescribing Engagement Network (OPEN) at the University of Michigan released evidence-based prescribing guidelines for 6 common surgical procedures. These were disseminated across 70 hospitals in Michigan, responsible for the majority of surgical care in the state. We hypothesized that the release of these guidelines would be associated with a decrease in the incidence of new persistent opioid use in Michigan compared with the rest of the United States.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: In June 2016, OPEN was established to address the problem of excessive opioid prescribing and pain management after acute care. Consisting of a partnership between clinicians, public health leaders, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, and Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan, OPEN collected data on patient-reported opioid use after surgery from hospitals throughout Michigan and used these data to develop evidence-based prescribing guidelines.19 In October 2017, OPEN released postoperative opioid prescribing guidelines for 6 procedure categories: laparoscopic cholecystectomy, laparoscopic appendectomy, minor hernia repair (open and laparoscopic inguinal, femoral, umbilical, and epigastric hernia repair), major hernia repair (open and laparoscopic ventral/incisional hernia repair), colectomy (open and laparoscopic), and hysterectomy (open, laparoscopic, and vaginal) (Supplemental Table 1, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401).16 These guidelines recommended prescribing a quantity of opioids equivalent to no more than the 75th percentile of patient-reported opioid use.20 Guidelines were disseminated via email, in-person presentations, video presentations, and web-based materials to 70 hospitals in Michigan through the Michigan Surgical Quality Collaborative (MSQC).21 OPEN guidelines were formally endorsed by the MSQC as a quality improvement initiative.

sec.title: Data Source and Study Cohort
sec.p: We used 100% fee-for-service Medicare claims (Part A, Part B, and Part D) in Michigan and a 20% national sample of fee-for-service Medicare claims outside of Michigan to identify patients undergoing surgery from January 1, 2013 to June 30, 2019. The study end date was chosen based on data availability and to allow for the evaluation of a 2-year post-intervention period. We included adult (age ≥18 y) Medicare beneficiaries who underwent any of the above surgical procedures for which OPEN had developed opioid prescribing guidelines (Supplemental Table 2, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401).

We identified only opioid-naive patients by excluding patients who filled 1 or more opioid prescriptions in the 12 months to 31 days before surgery.1,3 Patients were also excluded if they did not have continuous enrollment for at least 12 months before surgery and 6 months after surgery, were not discharged home after surgery, were still in the hospital on postoperative day 30, or underwent another surgery within 6 months of their index operation.

sec.title: Outcomes and Covariates
sec.p: The primary outcome was the incidence of new persistent opioid use after surgery. This was defined based on previously published criteria as filling at least 1 opioid prescription between postoperative days 4 to 90 and filling at least 1 additional opioid prescription between postoperative days 91 to 180.22,23 The secondary outcome was the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery. This was defined as the total milligrams of oral morphine equivalents (OME) dispensed in the 6 months after surgery in Part D pharmacy claims. Conversion to OME was performed to standardize differing potency between individual opioids.24

The exposure of interest was the occurrence of surgery in Michigan after the initiation of opioid mitigation strategies in 2016. Based on prior frameworks related to opioid prescribing, other patient covariates included age, sex, race and ethnicity, Elixhauser comorbidity index, history of tobacco use, alcohol or substance use disorders, mental health disorders, and pain disorders.25–27 Clinical covariates included the surgical procedure type, year of surgery, and admission status (inpatient vs. outpatient).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Descriptive statistics were calculated for patients who underwent surgery in Michigan and the rest of the United States. The main analysis of this study was a difference-in-differences model to evaluate the association of OPEN prescribing guidelines (released October 2017) with new persistent opioid use and opioid prescription quantity after surgery in Michigan.28 Since OPEN began community outreach in June 2016, we also evaluated the change in outcomes after this time point. Difference-in-difference analysis was used to account for ongoing trends in new persistent opioid use and opioid prescription quantity, both of which had been previously demonstrated to be decreasing nationally.4,29

Because there were differences in trends in outcomes between Michigan and non-Michigan patients before June 2016, we first calculated adjusted trends in new persistent opioid use and postoperative opioid prescription quantity for both groups. This followed previously described methods for calculating trend-adjusted models.30 We next performed a difference-in-differences analysis on trend-adjusted outcomes to assess the differential change in each outcome for patients who underwent surgery in Michigan compared with patients who underwent surgery outside of Michigan. To do so, we estimated a fixed effects linear regression model that included all covariates above, an indicator for the operation occurring in Michigan, an indicator for each time period (before June 2016, between July 2016 and September 2017, and after October 2017), and an interaction term between Michigan and each time period indicator.

We also performed 4 sensitivity analyses. First, to mitigate the potential effect of regional variation in the United States, we performed the same difference-in-differences analysis using 11 states in the US Midwest as the comparator group (Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, Wisconsin). Second, we further limited the geographic proximity of the comparator group and performed the same difference-in-differences analysis using Indiana and Wisconsin as comparators. Indiana and Wisconsin were chosen since Indiana did not have a collaborative quality improvement program like MSQC, and although Wisconsin had a collaborative quality improvement program, it did not focus on opioids during the study period. Third, given that patients with a diagnosis of cancer may be more likely to fill future opioid prescriptions due to cancer-related pain, which confounds accurate identification of new persistent opioid use, we performed the same difference-in-differences analysis excluding patients with a diagnosis of cancer. Finally, since patients with substance and drug use disorders are at increased risk of new persistent opioid use, we performed the same difference-in-differences analysis excluding patients with this diagnosis.

All statistical tests were performed using Stata version 16 (StataCorp LLC). Tests were 2-sided and significance was set to P<0.05. All statistical models used robust standard errors to account for clustering at the state level. The Institutional Review Board of the University of Michigan deemed this study of de-identified secondary data exempt from review and waived the requirement for informed consent. This study follows a preregistered study protocol available at https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.bwy6pfze and follows the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) reporting guidelines.31

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: We identified 24,908 opioid-naive patients who underwent 1 of the selected procedures in Michigan and 118,665 patients who underwent 1 of the selected procedures outside of Michigan between January 1, 2013 to June 30, 2019 (Supplemental Figure 1, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401). The mean age of patients in Michigan was 70.1 (11.6) years, and 11,774 (47.3%) patients were female. The mean age of patients outside of Michigan was 70.6 (10.9) years, and 57,210 (48.2%) patients were female. Full patient characteristics are displayed in Table 1.

sec.p: Figure 1 illustrates the adjusted incidence of new persistent opioid use during the study period. Compared with the rest of the United States, OPEN prescribing guidelines were associated with an additional 0.53 (95% CI 0.36-0.69) percentage point decrease (pp) in the incidence of new persistent opioid use in Michigan (Table 2). This additional decrease in the incidence of new persistent opioid use in Michigan after the release of OPEN prescribing guidelines was significant for laparoscopic cholecystectomy (additional 0.81 [95% CI 0.34-1.29] pp), minor hernia repair (additional 0.46 [95% CI 0.25-0.66] pp), and colectomy (additional 2.76 [95% CI 1.66-3.86] pp) (Supplemental Table 3, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401). OPEN prescribing guidelines were associated with a differential increase in the incidence of new persistent opioid use after laparoscopic appendectomy (additional 1.37 [95% CI 0.27-2.47] pp) and no differential change in the incidence of new persistent opioid use after major hernia repair or hysterectomy in Michigan. The establishment of OPEN in June of 2016 was not associated with a differential change in the incidence of new persistent opioid use in Michigan.

sec.p: Figure 2 illustrates adjusted postoperative opioid prescription quantity during the same time period. Compared with the rest of the United States, OPEN prescribing guidelines were associated with an additional 55.7 (95% CI 46.5-65.4) mg OME decrease in postoperative opioid prescription quantity in Michigan. This additional decrease in opioid prescription quantity in Michigan after the release of OPEN prescribing guidelines was significant for laparoscopic cholecystectomy (additional 95.3 [95% CI 74.6-116.0] mg OME), minor hernia repair (additional 42.7 [95% CI 38.2-47.2] mg OME), major hernia repair (additional 20.2 [95% CI 6.8-33.6] mg OME), colectomy (additional 78.5 [95% CI 47.0-110.0] mg OME), and hysterectomy (additional 34.3 [95% CI 1.9-66.7] mg OME). OPEN prescribing guidelines were not associated with a differential change in postoperative opioid prescription size after laparoscopic appendectomy in Michigan. The establishment of OPEN in June 2016 was associated with a differential 8.9 (95% CI 0.4-17.5) mg OME increase in postoperative opioid prescription quantity in Michigan. Supplemental Figure 2, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401 illustrates the proportion of patients who did not receive a postoperative opioid prescription in Michigan compared with the rest of the United States.

sec.title: Sensitivity Analyses
sec.p: Sensitivity analyses revealed similar differential decreases in both outcomes (Supplemental Table 4, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401). Compared with patients who underwent surgery in 11 neighboring Midwest states, OPEN prescribing guidelines were associated with an additional 0.61 (95% CI 0.30-0.91) pp decrease in the incidence of new persistent opioid use and an additional 52.3 (95% CI 32.3-72.2) mg OME decrease in postoperative opioid prescription quantity in Michigan (Supplemental Table 5, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401). Compared with patients who underwent surgery in Indiana and Wisconsin, the additional decrease in new persistent opioid use and opioid prescription quantity in Michigan was not significant (Supplemental Table 6, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401). After excluding patients with a diagnosis of cancer, OPEN prescribing guidelines were associated with an additional 0.64 (95% CI 0.44-0.84) pp decrease in the incidence of new persistent opioid use and an additional 64.2 (95% CI 53.8-74.5) mg OME decrease in postoperative opioid prescription quantity in Michigan (Supplemental Table 7, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401). Finally, after excluding patients with a diagnosis of substance and drug use disorder, OPEN prescribing guidelines were associated with an additional 0.38 (95% CI 0.21-0.54) pp decrease in the incidence of new persistent opioid use and an additional 30.9 (95% CI 24.7-37.2) mg OME decrease in postoperative opioid prescription quantity in Michigan (Supplemental Table 8, Supplemental Digital Content 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/E401).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Using a difference-in-differences analysis of Medicare claims, we found that the dissemination of evidence-based opioid prescribing guidelines was associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of new persistent opioid use and the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery in Michigan compared with other US states. Specifically, the incidence of new persistent opioid use decreased by ~26%, and the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery decreased by ~56% in Michigan, which was significantly greater than the decrease that occurred outside of Michigan during the same time period. These results suggest that evidence-based opioid prescribing guidelines are effective in reducing patients’ risk of developing ongoing opioid use after surgery.

Over the last several years, surgical episode has been recognized as a major driver of opioid-related morbidity in the United States. Compared with the rest of the world, where postoperative opioid prescriptions are rare, over 80% of patients in the United States receive an opioid prescription after surgery.32–34 These routine prescriptions exceed patients’ analgesic needs and place opioid-naïve patients at risk of continued opioid use after surgery.1,35 Although definitions of persistent postoperative opioid use vary, its incidence is estimated to range from 1% to 6.5% for common operations but can be as high as 20% after procedures such as cardiac surgery.7,36–40

Patients who transition from being opioid-naive to using opioids chronically after surgery are at increased risk of overdose and death.5 The risk of fatal overdose with long-term opioid therapy is well-documented.36,41 In addition, patients with chronic opioid prescriptions are over 8 times more likely to initiate injection drug use compared with opioid-naive patients.8 Finally, previously opioid-naive patients who develop chronic opioid use after surgery also experience increased healthcare utilization and expenditures, and the majority of these new prescriptions are ultimately managed by primary care physicians.6,10,11,42

To our knowledge, this is the first study to demonstrate that postoperative opioid prescribing guidelines based on patient-reported opioid use reduce the risk of new persistent opioid use after surgery. Although the incidence of new persistent use decreased nationally during the study period, patients who underwent surgery in Michigan had a greater reduction in the incidence of new persistent opioid use compared with patients undergoing the same operations outside of Michigan. The overall national decrease in new persistent opioid use after surgery has been reported in other studies and is likely related to greater opioid stewardship and awareness of the risks posed by opioids in the postoperative period.43 In addition, the baseline rate of new persistent opioid use was higher in Michigan compared with other states, which may be related to a generally higher prevalence of substance use disorder in Michigan.44 Despite this baseline difference, the significant difference-in-difference effect seen in Michigan suggests that prescribing guidelines play an important role in preventing opioid-naive patients from transitioning to chronic opioid use after surgery.

Our results also highlight an important relationship between the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery and the risk of developing new persistent opioid use. For example, patients who underwent colectomy had the greatest reduction in the quantity of opioids prescribed as well as the greatest reduction in new persistent opioid use. Conversely, laparoscopic appendectomy was the only procedure without a significant decrease in prescription quantity following guideline release and also the only procedure without a significant decrease in the incidence of persistent opioid use. This is consistent with prior work demonstrating that patients who receive the largest prescriptions after surgery are at the greatest risk of persistent opioid use.3,7,23 Therefore, the most likely mechanism by which evidence-based prescribing guidelines reduce the risk of persistent postoperative opioid use is by decreasing the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery. Importantly, prior work suggests that these reductions in prescription size do not negatively impact patient satisfaction or pain control.13,15,45

This study has several limitations. First, the differential change in new persistent opioid use and prescription size in Michigan may be subject to unmeasured confounders. For example, we did not account for legislation restricting opioid prescribing that went into effect during the study period. In recent years over 30 states have enacted laws limiting the supply of opioids that can be prescribed in the acute setting.46 However, by comparing Michigan with a representative sample of patients from all other 49 states, we believe that the impact of these laws would be evenly distributed across groups. Moreover, multiple prior studies suggest that policies limiting opioid prescribing had little to no effect on postoperative prescribing practice, likely because the amount needed for these operations is far below the typical 7-day limit imposed by these policies.47–49 Other guidelines were also released during this time, however, OPEN guidelines were formally endorsed and promoted by the MSQC and have previously been shown to have substantial adoption in Michigan.50 The generalizability of this study may be limited by the use of Medicare claims, which typically include older patients in whom opioid use and risk factors differ from other patient cohorts. Another limitation is that this study did not assess patient-reported outcomes, although we previously found that patient-reported satisfaction and pain control remained unchanged after the implementation of these guidelines.16 This study also did not include trends in opioid use and prescribing after 2019, which are equally important to evaluate to understand the sustainability and long-term effect of these guidelines. Finally, although we used a widely accepted definition of new persistent opioid use, this definition may nevertheless identify patients who continue filling opioids after surgery for reasons unrelated to their operation, such as a new diagnosis.51 Longitudinal studies of opioid-naive patients exposed to opioids perioperatively will be necessary to understand the trajectory of long-term opioid use after surgery.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Evidence-based prescribing guidelines were associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of new persistent opioid use and the quantity of opioids prescribed after surgery. Specifically, new persistent opioid use decreased by an additional 0.53 (95% CI 0.36-0.69) percentage points, and postoperative opioid prescription quantity decreased by an additional 55.7 (95% CI 46.5-65.4) mg OME in Michigan compared with the rest of the United States following guideline release. These results suggest that these prescribing guidelines may play an important role in protecting patients against opioid-related morbidity after surgery.
